article.title: Public KnowledgeAn Essay Concerning the Social Dimension of Science
article.author: Ziman, J.M.
article.text: Natural Science, whose internal development for three centuries is so uniform, well-documented and relatively self- generating, is an obvious candidate for such treatment. And having noticed the intellectual connections between the ideas of various scholars, we must surely pass on to an investigation of the social relations through which those connections are established. How do scientists teach, communicate with, promote, criticize, honour, give ear to, give patronage to, one another? What is the nature of the community to which they adhere?
